title: Where was the first computer invented? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is no easy answer to this question due to the many different classifications of computers. Inventions have came and gone in many places for many years with this computer to be use of now as follows: England: The word "computer" was first used in 1613 in the book The Yong Mans Gleanings by Richard Braithwaite and originally described a human who performed calculations or computations. The definition of a computer remained the same until the end of the 19th century, when the industrial revolution gave rise to machines whose primary purpose was calculating. England: In 1822, Charles Babbage conceptualized and began developing the Difference Engine, which is considered the first automatic computing machine. The Difference Engine was capable of computing several sets of numbers and making hard copies of the results. Babbage received some help with the development of the Difference Engine from Ada Lovelace, considered to be the first computer programmer for her work. Unfortunately, because of funding, Babbage was never able to complete a full-scale functional version of this machine. In 1837, Charles Babbage proposed the first general mechanical computer, the Analytical Engine. The Analytical Engine contained an ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit), basic flow control, punch cards (inspired by the Jacquard Loom), and integrated memory. It is the first general-purpose computer concept. Unfortunately, because of funding issues, this computer was also never built while Charles Babbage was alive. In 1910, Henry Babbage, Charles Babbage's youngest son, was able to complete a portion of this machine and perform basic calculations. Germany: The Z1 was created by German Konrad Zuse in his parents' living room between 1936 and 1938. It is considered to be the first electromagnetically binary programmable computer and the first functional modern computer. England: The Turing machine was first proposed by Alan Turing in 1936 and became the foundation for theories about computing and computers. The machine was a device that printed symbols on paper tape in a manner that emulated a person following a series of logical instructions. Without these fundamentals, we wouldn't have the computers we use today. USA: Short for Atanasoff-Berry Computer, the ABC began development by Professor John Vincent Atanasoff and graduate student Cliff Berry in 1937. Its development continued until 1942 at the Iowa State College (now Iowa State University). The ABC was an electrical computer that used more than 300 vacuum tubes for digital computation, including binary math and Boolean logic, and had no CPU (was not programmable). On October 19, 1973, US Federal Judge Earl R. Larson signed his decision that the ENIAC patent by J. Presper Eckert and John Mauchly was invalid. In the decision, Larson named Atanasoff the sole inventor. The ENIAC was invented by J. Presper Eckert and John Mauchly at the University of Pennsylvania and began construction in 1943 and was not completed until 1946. It occupied about 1,800 square feet and used about 18,000 vacuum tubes, weighing almost 50 tons. Although a judge later ruled the ABC computer was the first digital computer, many still consider the ENIAC to be the first digital computer because it was fully functional. England: The first computer to electronically store and execute a program was the SSEM (Small-Scale Experimental Machine), also known as the "Baby" or "Manchester Baby," in 1948. It was designed by Frederic Williams, and built by his protégée, Tom Kilburn, with the assistance of Geoff Tootill, at the University of Manchester, England. Kilburn wrote the first electronically-stored program, which finds the highest proper factor of an integer, using repeated subtraction rather than division. Kilburn's program was executed on June 21, 1948. The EDSAC, built and designed by Maurice Wilkes at the University of Cambridge Mathematical Laboratory in England. The EDSAC performed its first calculation on May 6, 1949. It was also the first computer to run a graphical computer game, "OXO," an implementation of tic-tac-toe displayed on a 6-inch cathode ray tube. USA: First delivered to the United States government in 1950, the UNIVAC 1101 or ERA 1101 is considered the first computer capable of storing and running a program from memory. Germany: In 1942, Konrad Zuse began working on the Z4 that later became the first commercial computer. The computer was sold to Eduard Stiefel, a mathematician of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, on July 12, 1950. USA: On April 7, 1953, IBM publicly introduced the 701, its first commercial scientific computer. USA: MIT introduces the Whirlwind machine on March 8, 1955, a revolutionary computer that was the first digital computer with magnetic core RAM and real-time graphics. -Bharath Vibushan

It depends on how you want to define computer. I am limiting this discussion to digital computers, and ignoring analog ones, which are a completely different beast. England, 1837. Charles Babbage describes the plans for his Analytical Engine, a mechanical digital computer using punched cards as input which was only partially constructed. It included sequential control, branching and looping, and would have been Turing-complete. In 1843, Ada Lovelace developed an algorithm that would have enabled the Engine to calculate a sequence of Bernoulli numbers, and is thus considered by some to be the world’s first computer programmer. England, 1936. 99 years later, the principle of the modern computer is first described by computer scientist Alan Turing in his seminal paper, On Computable Numbers. However because of his work in World War II breaking German codes, he won’t be involved in the actual design of an electronic computer until the Pilot-ACE project (1950). Germany, 1941. Konrad Zuse completes the Z3, the world's first working electromechanical programmable digital computer. It included about 2000 relays, did 22-bit floating point arithmetic and was considered marginally Turing complete (it had looping but not conditional branching). The German Aircraft Research Institute used it to perform statistical analyses of wing flutter. The original Z3 was destroyed on 21 December 1943 during an Allied bombardment of Berlin. US, 1942. John Atanasoff and Clifford Berry of Iowa State College (later University) develop the Atanasoff–Berry Computer (ABC), the first electronic digital computer. It used binary arithmetic, had about 300 vacuum tubes, and used capacitors fixed in a mechanically rotating drum for memory. The ABC was not programmable however, and was designed only to solve systems of linear equations. However 30 years later, it will be shown to have influenced the design of ENIAC, and thus invalidate the latter’s patents. England, 1943. Tommy Flowers at Bletchey Park designs Colossus, considered to be the world’s first programmable electronic digital computer, although it was programmed by switches and plugs and not by a stored program. Like the ABC, it is also special-purpose and only used to break the German Lorenz cipher. It used 2400 vacuum tubes (valves in the UK). It had paper-tape input and was capable of being configured to perform a variety of Boolean logical operations on its data, but it was not Turing-complete. Ten were built.  Colossus US, 1945. John von Neumann authors First Draft of a Report on the EDVAC, in which he describes a computer architecture in which programs and data are located in the same address space. Now called von Neumann architecture, it is the model for all computers used today, except those used in many embedded systems which use Harvard architecture (program and data in separate memory spaces). The British computers EDSAC at Cambridge (1949) and the Manchester Small-Scale Experimental Machine (1948) are the first working computers that followed his design. US, 1946. John Mauchly and J. Presper Eckert of the University of Pennsylvania design ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer), the world’s first general-purpose programmable electronic digital computer. It initially contained 17,468 vacuum tubes and used decimal rather than binary arithmetic. Punched cards were used for input and output.  ENIAC programming ENIAC was intended to be used to computer artillery firing tables for the Ballistics Research Laboratory, but the first programs run were actually used to study the feasibility of a hydrogen bomb. It was Turing complete. However like the Colossus, it was initially programmed using switches and plugs (see photo above). A read-only memory was added in 1948, which was first used in April. Mauchly and Eckert will later go on to design UNIVAC I, the first commercial computer first produced in the US in March, 1951. England, 1948. The Manchester SSEM (Small-Scale Experimental Machine) is developed as a testbed for using Williams electrostatic tubes as computer memory. It had a memory of only 32 words (32-bits each) and contained 550 vacuum tubes. It is considered by some to be the first world’s stored program electronic digital computer. It ran its first program out of electrostatic tube memory in June of 1948, but this was actually two months after ENIAC’s first demonstration of its read-only memory capability. The SSEM's successful demonstration quickly led to the construction of a more practical computer, the Manchester Mark 1. The first version was operational by April 1949, and it in turn led directly to the development of the Ferranti Mark 1, the world's first commercially available general-purpose computer, beating out the UNIVAC I by one month (February, 1951).  Manchester Mark 1

That depends on how you define computer. Traditionally ENIAC is considered to be first computer and it was constructed at University of Pennsylvania.However electronic stored-program binary computer like those we have today that title would belong to ENIAC direct successor EDVAC built also at University of Pennsylvania. The stored program part was most important as reprogramming ENIAC required changing wires and switches and with EDVAC it was just changing memory content.Of course there were many devices called computers before that. In military the foremost example was Torpedo Data Computer. Electromechanical non-reprogrammable device it was used to great extent by US Submarines. It handled trigonometric calculations required to properly aim torpedoes and was very effective in that role. It was quite sophisticated it accepted input from sonar, radar, submarine gyrocompass and can directly program torpedoes sitting in tubes. Quite useful machine to have on board.

“Where was the first computer made?” Since you did not say, digital computer, I looked up the term “analog computer” to see if that might apply. Are you familiar with the expression, “Eureka, I have found it!” This is attributed to Archimedes, in a bathtub and the idea of buoyancy. He took the same amount of gold as was supposed to be in a crown and then filled a pot with water to overflowing. He then carefully removed the pure gold and inserted the crown. The amount of water that overflowed showed the amount of impurities in the crown. At least this is the way I am recalling this. Would you call this an “analog computer?” If we were to observe a sundial. Would this be an “analog computer?” I understand, the Minoans constructed stone structures like Stone Hedge to calculate the longitude of places that were important to them, at 12 places around the world, including here in Michigan. They could tell the time of day to within seconds, from these structures, and the position around a globe, that we call “longitude”. Assuming this is true, would this be an “analog computer” from 2500 BC? (The British could not calculate longitude until modern times, using modern clocks.) Just a thought. Leon

I depends on your definition of “computer” and also “made”. If we define computers to be machines that carry out general computations according to programmed instructions then we can get somewhere close to the modern age. Otherwise there were mechanical calculators long before that. The first computer designed was the Analytical Engine in 1837 by Charles Babbage (Cambridge, UK) but it was never built. The first computer that ran a program was the Zuse Z3 in Berlin, Germany in 1941. Unfortunately it was destroyed by an Allied air raid in 1943. Its program was stored on paper tape. The first computer that stored its program in general memory along with its data was the Manchester (UK) University Small Scale Experimental Machine (Baby). It ran its first program on 21 June 1948 narrowly beating the American team building EDVAC (Aberdeen, Maryland, USA).

If you count Babbage’s work, England. A german created an electro mechanical computer called the Z1. There was a computer called the Colossus, invented in England for codebreaking. If you are looking for the first electronic computer ( that I know There was the Atanasoff-Berry Computer, using vacuum tubes, invented in USA ( Iowa.) I believe it predates the Eniac. This web page seems pretty complete in terms of “firsts” in computing hardware - When was the first computer invented?

In England. Mechanical - by Babbage in the 19th Century.This was never completed at the time although a replica is on display at Lo0ndon’s Science Museum.Electronic - by Tommy Flowers at the Post Office Research Centre in Dollis Hill, North London as part of the top-secret wartime codebreaker’s team at Bletchley Park in 1944. Tommy Flowers - WikipediaElectronic computers were independantly developed by Americans after the war while the British computers were still top-secret.Due to the cold war, Churchill ordered that the British computer (Colossus) was destroyed when better solutions to code breaking were found, but following the de-classification of the secrets in the late ‘90s, a replica was built at Bletchley Park.

Britain – A man named Charles Babbage laid down the schematics for a multifunction modern computer (which was called the analytical engine). A few things – it was entirely mechanical and he started designing it around 1835. He couldn’t get funding from the British government and it was never built. Another ‘”computer”, the Antikythera mechanism, is an entirely mechanical device that appears to calculate the phases of the moon using the irregular orbit of the moon, displayed current zoological positions, and several other astronomical positions. Found in 1901 off a Greek island of the same name; it is estimated to be approximately 2000 years old. Antikythera mechanism - Wikipedia Analytical Engine - Wikipedia

If your referring to the modern day term of a Computer, the definition of computer, then ENIAC is probably the best answer for the first computer. If you are referring to a conjugated form of Compute, the definition of compute, then the the Abacus would be the correct answer. I personally define a computer, as any device (electronic or mechanical) that takes a common task, or operation, and produces consistent results faster than if a person were to do it by hand. Up until the modern day definition of a computer, the Abacus would have been classified as the first computer (recorded history).

That depends on your definition of a computer. A machine used for processing numbers is what a computer is. For the purpose of this discussion, we will not count ( ha, a little pun there ) fingers and toes. So, the abacus was in use by early Chinese, Europeans and Russians. I don’t think anyone can claim to know who specifically, though. And even pinning down the when is not something that can be stated definitively. A long time ago is about the best I can do.

The United States Army Research Lab created ENIAC the first electronic digital computer. You can find a lot of info about it on Wikipedia or other sites: ENIAC To read more on the history of personal computers you can start with this article: Personal Computer History: The First 25 Years Prior to ENIAC there were various mechanical and manual computational devices (such as the abacus), but they aren’t really what most people think of when talking a “computer”.

Atanasoff-Berry Computer (1937-1942) is the first machine that meets our definition of a computer as seen through our modern eyes. Atanasoff–Berry computer - Wikipedia The American Atanasoff-Berry Computer predated Colossus, which was also a single purpose computer (that could only work on breaking one encryption) bit which was recently credited with being earlier than ENIAC. The ENIAC patents have been revoked, in light of the re-discovery of the obscure Atanasoff-Berry Computer. Ultimately the Atanasoff-Berry Computer is the device that inspired other modern computers to be made, and so it was the actual launch point of modern computers.

The Z1 was created by German Konrad Zuse in his parents' living room between 1936 and 1938. It is considered to be the first electro-mechanical binary programmable computer, and the first really functional modern computer.

Charles Babbage is the father of computers who designed the first successful, error-free automatic calculating machine and is considered to be the inspiration for modern programmable computers in the year 1821. Introduced to the world on Feb. 14, 1946, the ENIAC -- Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer -- was developed by the University of Pennsylvania's John Mauchly and J. Presper Eckert under a 1943 contract with the U.S. Army.[1] Footnotes[1] ENIAC, world's first digital computer, turns 66
My answer to the following question also answers this question: Bill Hall's answer to Who invented the computer?

Colossus was a set of computers developed by British codebreakers in the years 1943–1945 to help in the crypt-analysis of the Lorenz cipher. Colossus used thermionic valves to perform Boolean and counting operations. Wikipedia Regards, James.
That’s a pretty vague question, but I believe the following link will answer the question When was the first computer invented?
Mechanical analog? That would be the Antikythera device — an analog computer built about 200 BC in Greece antikythera mechanism - Google Searchtikythera device
It is at National Archaeological Museum of Athens
The world’s first electronic computer was ENIAC - Wikipedia
